titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Francis John Anscombe Papers
titlestmt.author: Preliminary Inventory by Rachael Nevins and Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:55

did.unittitle: Francis John Anscombe Papers

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist primarily of writings and teaching files which document the professional career of Francis Anscombe.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Teaching Files are unprocessed and may contain sensitive information or be in a physical state that would prohibit use. Researchers wishing to request access should email mssa.assist@yale.edu requesting specific box numbers in order to initiate the review process, which may take several weeks.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Francis John Anscombe Papers. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Statistics Department in 1991.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francis John Anscombe was born in Elstree, England on May 13, 1918. He received his B.A. degree from Cambridge University in 1939, and his M.A. degree in 1943. Anscombe was with the British Ministry of Supply from 1940-1945, and the Rothamsted Experimental Station from 1945-1947. He was a lecturer in math at Cambridge from 1948-1956, and a research associate, associate professor, and professor at Princeton from 1953-1963. Anscombe joined the faculty of Yale as a professor of statistics in 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist primarily of writings and teaching files which document the professional career of Francis Anscombe.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Inventory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Received from: Department of Statistics, 1991 Jun 14

These papers have been kept in the order in which they were received, and the original folder titles have been retained and/or expanded. The folders contain materials such as drafts of and letters and notes concerning the papers named in the following listing; the actual folder titles often refer to the event or publication for which a particular paper was written.
